name: 56 Master this 23 n8n node for 95% n8n understanding

parameters.content:
# üé¨ COMPLETE N8N NODES GUIDE
## Master n8n with These 23 Essential Nodes

This workflow covers 95% of what you'll ever need in automation.

üëâ Follow the flow from left to right
üëâ Each section builds on the previous one
üëâ Test each node as you learn

**Video Chapters:**
1. Triggers (How to Start)
2. Data Storage (Saving Info)
3. Data Transformation (Shaping Data)
4. Logic & Routing (Making Decisions)
5. External Connections (APIs)
6. AI Integration (Intelligence)
7. Utilities (Pro Features)

## üöÄ SECTION 1: TRIGGERS
### (How Automations Start)

Every automation needs a trigger - the event that kicks everything off.

**Choose based on your needs:**
- Testing? ‚Üí Manual Trigger
- Scheduled tasks? ‚Üí Schedule Trigger  
- Real-time events? ‚Üí Webhook
- App events? ‚Üí App-specific Triggers

**Pro Tip:** Always start with Manual Trigger when building. Switch to other triggers once tested!

### 1Ô∏è‚É£ MANUAL TRIGGER

**What it does:**
Lets you run the workflow manually by clicking "Execute Workflow"

**When to use:**
- Testing workflows during development
- On-demand execution
- Debugging issues
- Training and demos

**Best Practice:**
Start EVERY workflow with this while building. Replace it with the real trigger only when ready to go live.

**Example:**
Click ‚Üí Workflow runs ‚Üí Test your logic

### 2Ô∏è‚É£ SCHEDULE TRIGGER

**What it does:**
Runs your workflow automatically at specific times

**When to use:**
- Daily reports (every day at 9 AM)
- Weekly data syncs (Mondays at midnight)
- Monthly invoicing (1st of each month)
- Hourly monitoring (every 15 minutes)

**Settings:**
- Seconds/Minutes/Hours/Days/Weeks/Months
- Custom CRON expressions for complex schedules

**Examples:**
- Daily content generation ‚Üí 12:00 AM
- Weekly backup ‚Üí Sundays 2:00 AM
- Hourly API sync ‚Üí Every hour at :00

### 3Ô∏è‚É£ WEBHOOK TRIGGER

**What it does:**
Receives data from external sources in real-time

**When to use:**
- Form submissions (Typeform, Google Forms)
- Payment notifications (Stripe, PayPal)
- App events (Zapier, Make, custom apps)
- API integrations

**How it works:**
1. n8n gives you a unique URL
2. Send data to this URL from anywhere
3. Workflow triggers instantly

**Test vs Production:**
- Test URL: For development
- Production URL: For live workflows

**Example:**
Form Submit ‚Üí Webhook catches data ‚Üí Process it

### 4Ô∏è‚É£ APP TRIGGERS

**What it does:**
Starts workflow when something happens in a specific app

**Popular Triggers:**
- üìß Gmail: New email received
- üìù Typeform: Form submitted
- üí¨ Slack: New message posted
- üìÖ Google Calendar: Event created
- üõí Shopify: New order
- üìä Google Sheets: Row added

**How to find:**
Search for your app ‚Üí Look for "Trigger" nodes

**Example Flow:**
New Gmail ‚Üí Extract data ‚Üí Categorize ‚Üí Route to correct team

**500+ apps available!**

## üíæ SECTION 2: DATA STORAGE
### (Saving Information)

Store data from your automations for later use.

**Most Popular Options:**
1. Google Sheets - Easiest, everyone knows it
2. Airtable - More powerful, better for complex data
3. Databases - PostgreSQL, MySQL (advanced)

**Common Operations:**
- **Create/Append:** Add new records
- **Read/Get:** Retrieve existing data  
- **Update:** Modify records
- **Delete:** Remove records
- **Lookup:** Search for specific data

### 5Ô∏è‚É£ GOOGLE SHEETS

**What it does:**
Store and manage data in Google Spreadsheets

**Why use it:**
- ‚úÖ Everyone knows spreadsheets
- ‚úÖ Easy to view and edit manually
- ‚úÖ Great for small to medium data
- ‚úÖ Share with team members
- ‚úÖ No learning curve

**Common Operations:**
- **Append Row:** Add new data to bottom
- **Update Row:** Modify existing data
- **Lookup:** Search for specific values
- **Read:** Get all or specific rows
- **Delete:** Remove rows

**Perfect for:**
Leads, contact lists, order tracking, logs, reports

**Limitation:** Not ideal for 10,000+ rows

### 6Ô∏è‚É£ AIRTABLE

**What it does:**
Powerful database with spreadsheet interface

**Why use it:**
- ‚úÖ Better for relational data
- ‚úÖ Link records together
- ‚úÖ Multiple views (Grid, Calendar, Kanban)
- ‚úÖ Better data types (attachments, checkboxes)
- ‚úÖ More scalable than Sheets

**When to choose Airtable:**
- Customer ‚Üí Orders ‚Üí Products relationships
- Projects ‚Üí Tasks ‚Üí Team members
- Inventory management
- CRM systems

**Operations:**
Same as Sheets: Create, Read, Update, Delete, Search

**Pro Tip:** If your data has relationships, use Airtable. Otherwise, Sheets is simpler.

## üîÑ SECTION 3: DATA TRANSFORMATION
### (Manipulating & Shaping Data)

Transform data to match what you need.

**Core Concept:**
Data comes in one format ‚Üí Transform it ‚Üí Output in the format you need

**Key Nodes:**
- Split Out: Array ‚Üí Individual items
- Aggregate: Individual items ‚Üí Combined
- Set/Edit Fields: Create/modify fields
- Code: Custom transformations

**Think of it as:**
Raw ingredients ‚Üí Prep & cook ‚Üí Final dish

### 7Ô∏è‚É£ SPLIT OUT

**What it does:**
Converts an array (list) into individual items

**Why you need it:**
Most APIs return lists of data. To process each item individually, you must split them out.

**Visual:**
```
BEFORE: 1 item (array of 10 emails)
AFTER: 10 items (each email separate)
```

**Common Use Cases:**
- Process each email individually
- Add each contact to database one by one
- Send personalized message to each person
- Check each order status

**Example Flow:**
Get contacts from API (1 item with 50 contacts) ‚Üí Split Out ‚Üí Now 50 items ‚Üí Process each

**Remember:** Can't add arrays to databases directly. Must split first!

### 8Ô∏è‚É£ AGGREGATE

**What it does:**
Combines multiple items back into one

**Why you need it:**
Opposite of Split Out. After processing items individually, combine them for the next step.

**Visual:**
```
BEFORE: 10 items (processed separately)
AFTER: 1 item (all combined)
```

**Common Use Cases:**
- Create summary reports
- Combine results before sending email
- Prepare data for bulk operations
- Generate combined CSV/Excel file

**Example Flow:**
Split Out 20 contacts ‚Üí Process each ‚Üí Aggregate ‚Üí Send one email with all results

**Pro Tip:** Use before sending to email/Slack to avoid 20 separate messages!

### 9Ô∏è‚É£ SET / EDIT FIELDS

**What it does:**
Create new fields or modify existing ones

**Why you need it:**
Shape data to match what the next step needs

**Common Operations:**
- Combine fields: firstName + lastName = fullName
- Add timestamps: Set 'createdAt' = now
- Set status: Mark as 'processed'
- Calculate values: quantity √ó price = total
- Rename fields: 'email_address' ‚Üí 'email'

**Example Transformations:**
```
INPUT: { first: 'John', last: 'Doe' }
SET: fullName = first + ' ' + last
OUTPUT: { fullName: 'John Doe' }
```

**Pro Tip:** Use this before sending to other apps to match their field names!

### üîü CODE NODE

**What it does:**
Write custom JavaScript for complex transformations

**When to use:**
- Complex data transformations (7+ nodes worth)
- Custom calculations
- Advanced text parsing
- Date/time manipulations
- API response processing

**Don't worry about coding:**
- ChatGPT can write code for you!
- Describe what you need ‚Üí Paste code ‚Üí Done

**Example Uses:**
- Parse unstructured text
- Complex IF/THEN logic
- Loop through nested data
- Custom formatting

**Template:**
```javascript
const items = $input.all();
return items.map(item => ({
  json: { /* your transformation */ }
}));
```

## üéØ SECTION 4: LOGIC & ROUTING
### (Making Decisions)

Control the flow based on conditions.

**The Power of Logic:**
Different data = Different actions

**Key Nodes:**
- IF: True or False (2 paths)
- Switch: Multiple conditions (3+ paths)
- Filter: Stop if conditions not met
- Merge: Combine parallel branches

**Real-World Examples:**
- IF email urgent ‚Üí Slack, else ‚Üí ticket
- Switch by category ‚Üí different teams
- Filter only orders > $100
- Merge data from 2 APIs

### 1Ô∏è‚É£1Ô∏è‚É£ IF NODE

**What it does:**
Simple True/False branching

**When to use:**
When you have 2 possible paths

**Common Conditions:**
- Email contains 'urgent' ‚Üí True
- Price > $1000 ‚Üí True  
- Status equals 'approved' ‚Üí True
- Date is today ‚Üí True

**Example Flows:**
```
IF urgent email
  TRUE ‚Üí Send Slack alert
  FALSE ‚Üí Create ticket

IF order > $500
  TRUE ‚Üí Manager approval
  FALSE ‚Üí Auto-approve
```

**Conditions Available:**
- Equals, Not Equals
- Contains, Not Contains
- Greater than, Less than
- Is Empty, Is Not Empty
- Exists, Does Not Exist

### 1Ô∏è‚É£2Ô∏è‚É£ SWITCH NODE

**What it does:**
Route to multiple paths based on conditions

**When to use:**
When you have 3+ possible outcomes

**Advantage over IF:**
Cleaner than chaining multiple IF nodes

**Example: Email Router**
```
Switch by email category:
- 'Support' ‚Üí Zendesk
- 'Sales' ‚Üí HubSpot
- 'Billing' ‚Üí Accounting
- 'General' ‚Üí Default inbox
```

**Example: Lead Scorer**
```
Switch by lead score:
- Score > 80 ‚Üí Hot leads
- Score 50-80 ‚Üí Warm leads  
- Score < 50 ‚Üí Cold leads
```

**Pro Tip:** You can add unlimited routing rules. Each gets its own output path!

### 1Ô∏è‚É£3Ô∏è‚É£ FILTER NODE

**What it does:**
STOP workflow if conditions aren't met

**Key Difference from IF:**
- IF: Continue on both paths
- Filter: STOP if false, continue if true

**Why use it:**
- Save processing time
- Reduce API calls
- Prevent unnecessary actions

**Common Use Cases:**
```
‚úÖ Only process orders > $50
‚úÖ Only continue if email valid
‚úÖ Only proceed if status = 'active'
‚úÖ Only process during business hours
‚úÖ Only if user verified
```

**Pro Tip:** Put Filter nodes EARLY in workflows to stop unnecessary processing immediately!

**Example:**
Filter: Order > $100 ‚Üí FALSE? Stops here. TRUE? Continues.

### 1Ô∏è‚É£4Ô∏è‚É£ MERGE NODE

**What it does:**
Combine data from multiple branches

**When to use:**
Workflow splits into parallel paths, then need to combine results

**Modes:**
- **Append:** Combine items (default)
- **Combine:** Merge fields from both inputs
- **Choose Branch:** Pick one branch's data

**Common Pattern:**
```
Start
  ‚Üì
  Split into 2 paths:
  ‚Üí Path A: Get customer data
  ‚Üí Path B: Get order history
  ‚Üì
Merge both ‚Üí Now have combined data
  ‚Üì
Continue with full dataset
```

**Real Example:**
Fetch from API + Query Database ‚Üí Merge ‚Üí Send combined report

**Pro Tip:** Use when you need data from 2+ sources before continuing!

## üåê SECTION 5: EXTERNAL CONNECTIONS
### (APIs & Integrations)

Connect to ANY web service, even without native nodes.

**The Reality:**
n8n has ~400 app nodes.
The internet has millions of APIs.

**HTTP Request = Universal Connector**

**What You'll Learn:**
- Call any API
- Send/receive data
- Authenticate
- Handle responses

**This unlocks EVERYTHING!**

### 1Ô∏è‚É£5Ô∏è‚É£ HTTP REQUEST

**What it does:**
Connect to ANY web service or API

**Why it's powerful:**
Only 400 apps have native n8n nodes. Millions have APIs. This connects you to ALL of them!

**HTTP Methods:**
- **GET:** Retrieve data (read)
- **POST:** Send/create data (create)
- **PUT/PATCH:** Update existing data (update)
- **DELETE:** Remove data (delete)

**Common Use Cases:**
- Custom internal APIs
- New SaaS tools without n8n integration
- Webhooks to other services
- Government/public data APIs
- Weather, maps, finance APIs

**Authentication:**
Supports: API Keys, OAuth2, Basic Auth, Bearer Token

**Example:**
GET weather data ‚Üí POST to Slack ‚Üí Update Sheets

### 1Ô∏è‚É£6Ô∏è‚É£ RESPOND TO WEBHOOK

**What it does:**
Send data back to the app that triggered your workflow

**When to use:**
- Form submissions need confirmation
- API calls expect responses
- Create two-way communication
- Return processing results

**How it works:**
```
1. Webhook receives data
2. Workflow processes it
3. Respond to Webhook sends result back
```

**Example Flow:**
```
Webhook (form submit)
  ‚Üì
Process data
  ‚Üì
Save to database
  ‚Üì
Respond to Webhook: 'Success! Saved.'
  ‚Üì
Form shows confirmation message
```

**Response Options:**
Text, JSON, HTML, Custom status codes

**Pro Tip:** Always pair with Webhook trigger for real-time feedback!

## ü§ñ SECTION 6: AI INTEGRATION
### (Adding Intelligence)

Make your workflows smart with AI.

**AI Changes Everything:**
- Understand unstructured data
- Make smart decisions
- Generate content
- Extract information
- Categorize automatically

**Two Main Approaches:**
1. **AI Node:** Single-task AI (like asking ChatGPT)
2. **AI Agent:** Multi-step AI with tools (like a smart assistant)

**This is where automation becomes intelligent!**

### 1Ô∏è‚É£7Ô∏è‚É£ OPENAI / CHATGPT NODE

**What it does:**
Single-task AI processing (like using ChatGPT in your workflow)

**Common Use Cases:**
- üìù Summarize emails/documents
- üè∑Ô∏è Categorize content (support/sales/billing)
- ‚úçÔ∏è Generate responses/content
- üîç Extract data from text
- üåê Translate languages
- ‚úÖ Check grammar/spelling
- üí° Make recommendations

**Prompt Types:**
- **System:** "You are a helpful assistant"
- **User:** "Summarize this email in 2 sentences"
- **Assistant:** Give examples

**Models Available:**
GPT-4, GPT-4 Turbo, GPT-3.5

**Example Flow:**
Email arrives ‚Üí AI categorizes ‚Üí Switch routes to team

**Pro Tip:** Clear, specific prompts = better results!

### 1Ô∏è‚É£8Ô∏è‚É£ AI AGENT (Advanced)

**What it does:**
AI assistant that can use tools and take actions

**Key Difference from OpenAI Node:**
- OpenAI: One task, one response
- AI Agent: Multi-step, uses tools, remembers context

**What makes it powerful:**
‚úÖ Conversational (remembers chat history)
‚úÖ Can use multiple tools (Gmail, Sheets, Calendar)
‚úÖ Makes decisions on what to do next
‚úÖ Takes actions on your behalf

**Example Conversation:**
```
You: 'Schedule meeting with John next week'
Agent: 
  1. Checks your calendar (Tool: Google Calendar)
  2. Finds available slot
  3. Drafts email (Tool: Gmail)
  4. Creates calendar event
  5. Responds: 'Meeting scheduled for Tuesday 2 PM'
```

**Use Cases:**
Personal assistant, customer support bot, task automation

**Pro Tip:** This is like having a smart employee who knows how to use all your apps!

## ‚öôÔ∏è SECTION 7: ESSENTIAL UTILITIES
### (Power Features & Helpers)

Nodes that make your workflows more powerful, reliable, and professional.

**What You'll Learn:**
- Add delays and pauses
- Handle errors gracefully
- Create modular workflows
- Control execution flow
- Build production-ready automations

**These separate beginners from pros!**

### 1Ô∏è‚É£9Ô∏è‚É£ WAIT NODE

**What it does:**
Pause workflow execution for a specified time

**When to use:**
- ‚è±Ô∏è Rate limiting (don't hit API limits)
- ‚è≥ Give external system time to process
- üìÖ Schedule follow-ups
- üîÑ Retry after failure
- üö¶ Control execution speed

**Wait Options:**
- Seconds, Minutes, Hours, Days
- Until specific date/time
- For webhook response

**Common Examples:**
```
Send welcome email
  ‚Üì
Wait 2 days
  ‚Üì
Send follow-up email

OR

Create user account
  ‚Üì  
Wait 10 seconds (system processing)
  ‚Üì
Fetch user details
```

**Pro Tip:** Use between API calls to avoid rate limits (e.g., 100 requests/minute = wait 0.6s between calls)

### 2Ô∏è‚É£0Ô∏è‚É£ ERROR TRIGGER

**What it does:**
Catches workflow failures and takes action

**Why it's CRITICAL:**
Without this, you won't know when workflows break!

**What it catches:**
- ‚ùå API errors
- ‚ùå Authentication failures  
- ‚ùå Timeout errors
- ‚ùå Invalid data
- ‚ùå Node execution failures

**Common Actions:**
- üì¢ Send Slack alert
- üìß Email admin
- üìä Log to Google Sheets
- üîÑ Retry workflow
- üì± SMS notification

**Example Setup:**
```
Error Trigger (catches any workflow failure)
  ‚Üì
Format error message
  ‚Üì
Send to Slack: 'Workflow X failed: [error details]'
```

**Pro Tip:** Create ONE error handling workflow, then use it for all your workflows!

**‚ö†Ô∏è MUST-HAVE for production workflows!**

### 2Ô∏è‚É£1Ô∏è‚É£ EXECUTE WORKFLOW

**What it does:**
Trigger another workflow from the current one

**Why use it:**
Build modular, reusable automations

**Benefits:**
‚úÖ Reuse workflows (don't rebuild same logic)
‚úÖ Keep workflows organized
‚úÖ Easier to maintain
‚úÖ Separate concerns

**Common Patterns:**
```
MAIN WORKFLOW:
  Get new leads
    ‚Üì
  Execute: 'Enrich Lead Data' workflow
    ‚Üì
  Execute: 'Send to CRM' workflow
    ‚Üì
  Execute: 'Notify Team' workflow
```

**Real Example:**
- Workflow A: Process order
- Workflow B: Send invoice (reusable)
- Workflow C: Update inventory (reusable)

Workflow A executes B and C!

**Pro Tip:** Create a library of reusable workflows for common tasks!

### 2Ô∏è‚É£2Ô∏è‚É£ LOOP OVER ITEMS

**What it does:**
Process items one at a time with delays between each

**Why you need it:**
Prevent API rate limits!

**The Problem:**
```
100 contacts ‚Üí Process all at once
= 100 API calls in 1 second
= Rate limit error! ‚ùå
```

**The Solution:**
```
100 contacts ‚Üí Loop Over Items
  ‚Üì
Process item 1 ‚Üí Wait 1 second
Process item 2 ‚Üí Wait 1 second
Process item 3 ‚Üí Wait 1 second
...
= Stays within rate limits ‚úÖ
```

**Settings:**
- Max iterations (how many to process)
- Pause between iterations (delay)

**Use Cases:**
- Bulk email sending (don't spam)
- API calls with rate limits
- Sequential processing
- Controlled batch operations

**Pro Tip:** Check the API's rate limit (e.g., 60/minute) and set your delay accordingly!

## üéØ BEST PRACTICES
### Essential Tips for Success

**1. START SIMPLE**
‚úÖ Use Manual Trigger for testing
‚úÖ Build one node at a time
‚úÖ Test after each node
‚úÖ Don't build everything at once

**2. ERROR HANDLING**
‚úÖ ALWAYS add Error Trigger workflow
‚úÖ Use Try/Catch patterns with IF nodes
‚úÖ Log failures (Sheets/Slack/Email)
‚úÖ Add helpful error messages

**3. PERFORMANCE**
‚úÖ Use Filter early (stop unnecessary processing)
‚úÖ Batch operations when possible
‚úÖ Add Wait nodes for rate limits
‚úÖ Use Loop for controlled processing

**4. ORGANIZATION**
‚úÖ Name nodes clearly (not just 'HTTP Request')
‚úÖ Use Sticky Notes for documentation
‚úÖ Group related workflows
‚úÖ Version your workflows

## üî• 5 COMMON WORKFLOW PATTERNS
### Copy These Templates!

**PATTERN 1: Form to Database**
```
Webhook (form submission)
  ‚Üì
Set (format data)
  ‚Üì
Google Sheets (save)
  ‚Üì
Respond to Webhook (confirmation)
```

**PATTERN 2: Scheduled Report**
```
Schedule (daily 9 AM)
  ‚Üì
HTTP Request (fetch data)
  ‚Üì
AI (summarize)
  ‚Üì
Email (send report)
```

**PATTERN 3: Smart Email Router**
```
Gmail Trigger (new email)
  ‚Üì
AI (categorize: support/sales/billing)
  ‚Üì
Switch (route by category)
  ‚Üì
Different actions per category
```

**PATTERN 4: Data Sync**
```
Schedule (hourly)
  ‚Üì
App A (get new records)
  ‚Üì
Filter (only modified)
  ‚Üì
Transform (format)
  ‚Üì
App B (update/create)
```

**PATTERN 5: Error Notification**
```
Error Trigger (any workflow fails)
  ‚Üì
Set (format error details)
  ‚Üì
Slack (notify team)
  ‚Üì
Google Sheets (log error)
```

## üìö LEARNING RESOURCES

**Official n8n Resources:**
üîó docs.n8n.io - Complete documentation
üîó community.n8n.io - Community forum
üîó n8n.io/workflows - 1000+ workflow templates

**Practice Exercise:**
Build these 3 workflows to master the basics:

**Exercise 1 (Beginner):**
Manual Trigger ‚Üí HTTP Request (get weather) ‚Üí Set (format) ‚Üí Manual output

**Exercise 2 (Intermediate):**
Webhook ‚Üí Split Out (array) ‚Üí Loop Through ‚Üí Google Sheets (append each)

**Exercise 3 (Advanced):**
Schedule ‚Üí HTTP Request ‚Üí AI (analyze) ‚Üí IF (check) ‚Üí Switch (route) ‚Üí Multiple endpoints

**Next Steps:**
1. Import this workflow to your n8n
2. Test each node individually  
3. Build one complete automation
4. Share your success! üéâ

## ‚ö° QUICK REFERENCE GUIDE

**TRIGGERS (Start)**
‚Ä¢ Manual - Testing
‚Ä¢ Schedule - Time-based
‚Ä¢ Webhook - Real-time events
‚Ä¢ Apps - 400+ integrations

**STORAGE (Save)**
‚Ä¢ Google Sheets - Simple
‚Ä¢ Airtable - Advanced
‚Ä¢ Databases - Production

**TRANSFORM (Shape)**
‚Ä¢ Split Out - Array ‚Üí Items
‚Ä¢ Aggregate - Items ‚Üí One
‚Ä¢ Set - Create/modify fields
‚Ä¢ Code - Custom logic

**LOGIC (Decide)**
‚Ä¢ IF - True/False
‚Ä¢ Switch - Multiple paths
‚Ä¢ Filter - Stop if false
‚Ä¢ Merge - Combine branches

**CONNECT (External)**
‚Ä¢ HTTP Request - Any API
‚Ä¢ Respond - Send back data

**AI (Intelligence)**
‚Ä¢ OpenAI - Single task
‚Ä¢ AI Agent - Multi-step

**UTILITIES (Helpers)**
‚Ä¢ Wait - Add delays
‚Ä¢ Error Trigger - Catch failures
‚Ä¢ Execute Workflow - Call others
‚Ä¢ Loop - Controlled iteration

**üìå Bookmark this for quick reference!**

### 6Ô∏è‚É£ N8N DATA TABLES

**What it does:**
Native database built directly into n8n - no external service needed

**Why use it:**
- ‚úÖ **No setup required** - Works immediately, no credentials
- ‚úÖ **Lives in n8n** - Data stays in your instance
- ‚úÖ **Fast performance** - Direct access, no API calls
- ‚úÖ **Free storage** - No external service costs
- ‚úÖ **Great for testing** - Quick prototyping

**When to choose n8n Data Tables:**
- Internal automation data (logs, status tracking)
- Temporary data storage during workflows
- Cache/lookup tables
- Small to medium datasets (under 10,000 records)
- Don't want external service setup

**When NOT to use:**
- ‚ùå Need to access data outside n8n
- ‚ùå Team needs spreadsheet view/editing
- ‚ùå Very large datasets (100,000+ records)

**Operations:**
Insert, Read, Update, Delete, Search

**Pro Tip:** 
Use n8n Tables for **workflow-only data**. Use Google Sheets when non-technical team members need access.

**Examples:**
- Store processed IDs (avoid duplicates)
- Cache API responses
- Track workflow execution history
- Maintain lookup tables

assignments.name: items
items
items
